name: 2-phenylhydroquinone
Reason: 2-phenylhydroquinone has a melting point that can be predicted by considering its structural components. The basic unit for comparison is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius. The phenyl group (c1ccc(cc1)C) adds approximately +30 degrees Celsius due to increasing the molecular weight and rigidity of the structure. The hydroquinone moiety (Oc2cc(ccc2O)O) introduces two phenolic hydroxyl groups, which can participate in hydrogen bonding, raising the melting point by approximately +20 degrees Celsius. The ketone group (O) can also contribute to the melting point, but the exact impact is difficult to quantify without experimental data or detailed computational studies.
